Posts.Content: Hi LucyB. Telling your daughter will be hard and emotional. I had to tell my daughters age 11 & 12 a few weeks ago. We felt it was better to be honest but not make false promises. They took it hard and asked if I would die. I told them hopefully when the operation was over and with some treatment that would be the end of it. The BCN advised us its best to be honest. They have had support at school which has been really helpful for them.  I am not a single parent but maybe you could ask a family member or friend to be there with you. I can understand you wanting to keep everything normal. But it isnt normal and it will be hard to hide that from her. We have just kept our lives the same as much as we can. I have tried not to get upset in front of them. Everyone has a different way of dealing with it & hoping you can find what is right for you. Xx

Posts.Title: MRI scan -copper coil IUD

Posts.Content: I too had my first daughter at 40 & she is now almost 13. My other daughter is almost 12. I waited until i knew the results of biopsy & the plan before i told them i had breast cancer. It was heartbreaking telling them & they did cry & ask if i would die. I didnt make false promises but did tell them that with surgery & other treatment doctors are hoping it will all be gone. They accepted that.  I told the tutor at school & they have arranged support for them. I gave them a notebook to write worries & thoughts in. They ask random questions from time to time.  Waiting is the hardest thing. Try to keep your thoughts positive but realistic. I know how your mind will be in overdrive wondering about the what ifs.  I  was diagnosed in january and am 4 weekes post mastectomy & Diep and start chemo on friday. This forum is brilliant to ask questions and chat to others.  Good luck with whatever you decide to tell your daughter & when. Let us all know how you get on. Xx

Posts.Content: Hi anne. Its a big and complex operation so lots of internal structures to heal. I am 11 months after diep and have normal movement as before op. I think i was quite diligent in doing the exercises and had quite good movement after 2 months as I remember. You may need physio so ask your consultant about it. I do get aching later in the day. Not painful but just an ache on the side under the armpit.  It is very early days yet. Wishing you a good recovery  tracey
Posts.Title: Arm movement, tightness and pain following mastectomy, axillary clearance...

Posts.Content: Had first EC chemo yesterday and did cold cap which was painful at first but managed to get through it. Had chemo about 11.30 and at 5pm last night started with really bad nausea, headache, tiredness, metal taste in mouth. I was expecting that monday after i finish steroids but not so soon. I took ondansatron as prescribed which was no help. then took the domperidone they gave me for next week but also no effect. Bad headache still despite regular paracetamol. Anyone using anything else for sickness/ nausea? I do not want to start vomiting as only 5 week post Diep. also didnt eat naything from lunch yesterday to this morning when i managed to force in toast so i could take the steroids. My daughter then said i looked like a beetroot-kids are so honest!!
